awd_titl_txt: CAREER: Structured Output Models of Recommendations, Activities, and Behavior
awd_abstract_narration:
This project will investigate predictive models of human behavior that are capable of estimating rich, structured outputs. Such predictive models underlie many of the most important computing systems in science and industry, ranging from e-Commerce to personalized healthcare. While existing models (i.e., "recommender systems") typcially focus on simple predictions (a user's next click or star rating, a patient's next symptom, etc.), this project shall develop models capable of generating outputs in the form of text, images, and sequences. These new modalities of predictive modeling will allow personalized recommender systems to be adapted to answer complex questions, predict nuanced reactions, and even to design new content that elicits a certain reaction.

The project's technical approach combines ideas from personalized recommender systems with newly-emerging techniques for generative modeling. Ideas from recommender systems can be used to handle issues like personalization, subjectivity, or other variance that arises due to differences between individuals; ideas from generative modeling allow complex outputs (text, images, sequences) to be generated. This technical contribution can be viewed either as a new form of recommender system capable of handling more complex queries, or alternately as a new suite of generative modeling approaches that can account for variance between individuals. This project will have impact to applications where complex, high-dimensional data meets issues of personalization and subjectivity. Specific examples to be investigated include online activity traces, e-Commerce, and personalized health.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Computer and Information Science and Engineering

por.por_cntn:
This project investigated predictive models of human behavior that are capable of estimating rich, structured outputs. Primary directions of the project included (a) recommender systems, especially systems involving rich data such as images and dialog; (b) systems for clinical Natural Language Processing (NLP); and (c) investigations of the fairness implications of personalization in these contexts.

Core themes in recommender systems included the emerging area of conversational recommendation, whereby users interact with recommendation engines via natural-language interfaces. This has become an especially important topic following the emergence of practical Large Language Models (LLMs) in recent years, and their potential to facilitate more expressive recommendation modalities. We also explored related topics in recommendation, including image-aware recommendation (e.g. for fashion scenarios), and various forms of recommendation involving structured data (text, images, time-series, weather, etc.).

Core themes in clinical natural language processing included aspects such as clinical report generation (e.g. generating a clinical report from a radiology image), and medical report disambiguation (e.g. "rewriting" a clinical note to make the outcome understandable by a patient). This project also contributed to the emerging direction of developing LLMs for clinical use cases.

Within Fair Machine Learning we studied problems at the intersection of fairness and NLP, and problems at the intersection of fairness and recommendation. Examples include work on various biases in recommender systems and in natural language generation, and strategies to mitigate such biases.

Narrowly, the above work connects to the development of better recommender systems, including the types of systems that drive user-facing recommendations on popular e-commerce platforms, by making them richer, more empathetic to user needs, expressive, explainable, etc. Given the significant societal impact of such applications (which are ubiquitous on e-commerce and social media websites), it is critical to develop better models and understand the risks involved in their deployment (e.g. biases, filter bubbles, etc.).

More broadly, the above work connects to personalization in large range of settings, whenever predictive algorithms are needed that personalize their outputs to individual users. Including our work in clinical NLP, personalized machine learning systems have applications in text, audio, music, and personalized health, among others.


Last Modified: 08/02/2023
Modified by: Julian J Mcauley
